class vizasm.analysis.asm.cpu.arm.AsmRegEx_arm.AsmRegEx_arm[source]¶

Bases: vizasm.analysis.asm.cpu.AsmRegEx.AsmRegEx

Contains regular expressions (mostly in verbose mode) used for analyzing the assembler file on the arm architecture.

Parameters:

RE_IVAR :

match e.g. “IVAR_0x291c”

RE_CLASSREF :

match e.g. “@bind__OBJC_CLASS_$_UIScreen”

RE_IMP_SYMBOLSTUB :

match e.g “imp___symbolstub1__objc_msgSend”

RE_IMP_NL_SYMBOL_PTR :

match e.g. “@imp___nl_symbol_ptr__objc_retain”

RE_ASSINGMENT_SPLIT :

match e.g. “ldr r8, [sp], #0x4” or

“ldr r1, [r0] ” or “cvtss2sd xmm2, xmm2”

RE_OFFSET_ADDRESSING :

match .e.g “[sp, #0x8]”

RE_CALL_INSTRUCTION :

match e.g. “blx imp___symbolstub1__objc_msgSend”

RE_ADD :

match e.g. “add r7, sp, #0xc” or

“add r7, sp” or “add r7, #0xc”

RE_REGISTER :

match e.g. “ro”

RE_ANNOTATED_SUPERCALL :

match e.g. ”; call to super: 0xbb4e”

Methods

compiled_re(regex[, flags]) Returns a compiled regex pattern object Flags will only be passed if not None.
compiled_re_stack(stack_pointer_name, ...) Return a compiled regular expression that matches e.g.
compiled_re_stack_push_via_stm(...) Read a stack push via “stm” like e.g.
compiled_vre(regex[, flags]) Returns a compiled regex pattern object
is_entrypoint(asmline) Check if line is entry point in asm file (See AsmRegEx.RE_MATCH_ENTRYPOINT)
is_method_implementation(asmline) Indicates if a line is a CategoryClass or method implementation.
method_implementation_is_static(...) Returns if the method is static
stack_pointer_sub(stack_pointer_str, asmline) Read a line like e.g.
RE_ADD = '\n add\\w* # add\n \\s+ # whitespace\n (?P<dest>\\w+) # r7\n , # ,\n \\s* # whitespace\n (?P<operand1>\\#?\\w+) # sp\n (\n ,\\s* # , whitespace\n (?P<operand2>\\#?\\w+) # #0xc\n )*\n '¶
RE_ADD_GR_DEST = 'dest'¶
RE_ADD_GR_OPERAND1 = 'operand1'¶
RE_ADD_GR_OPERAND2 = 'operand2'¶
RE_ANNOTATED_SUPERCALL = '\n call\\s+to\\s+super[:]\\s+ # "; call to super:" \n (?P<superref_addr>0x\\w+) # 0xbb4e\n '¶
RE_ANNOTATED_SUPERCALL_GR_SUPERREF_ADDR = 'superref_addr'¶
RE_ASSINGMENT_SPLIT = '\n (?P<op>(add|mov|ldr|.*cvt|st(m|r)).*?) # ldr\n \\s+\n (?P<val1>.*?) # r8\n ,\\s* # ,\n =? # optional "=" for ldr\n (?P<val2>.*) # [sp], #0x4\n '¶
RE_ASSINGMENT_SPLIT_GR_OP = 'op'¶
RE_ASSINGMENT_SPLIT_GR_VAL1 = 'val1'¶
RE_ASSINGMENT_SPLIT_GR_VAL2 = 'val2'¶
RE_CALL_INSTRUCTION = '\n blx? # bl or blx\n \\s* # whitespace\n (?P<called>\\S+) # called\n '¶
RE_CALL_INSTRUCTION_GR_CALLED = 'called'¶
RE_CLASSREF = '\n @bind[_]{2}OBJC[_]CLASS[_][$][_] # @bind__OBJC_CLASS_$_\n (?P<classref>\\S+) # UIScreen\n '¶
RE_CLASSREF_GR_CLASSREF = 'classref'¶
RE_IMP_NL_SYMBOL_PTR = '\n @imp[_]{3}nl[_]symbol[_]ptr[_]{2} # @imp___nl_symbol_ptr__\n (?P<name>\\S+) # objc_retain\n '¶
RE_IMP_NL_SYMBOL_PTR_GR_NAME = 'name'¶
RE_IMP_STUBS_GR_IMP_SYMBOLSTUB = 'imp_symbolstub'¶
RE_IMP_SYMBOLSTUB = '\n (?:imp[_]{3}symbolstub1[_]{2,}) # imp___symbolstub1__\n (?P<imp_symbolstub>.*) # objc_msgSend\n '¶
RE_IVAR = '\n IVAR[_] # IVAR_\n (?P<ivar_addr>\\S+) # 0x291c\n '¶
RE_IVAR_GR_NAME = 'ivar_addr'¶
RE_OFFSET_ADDRESSING = '\n \\[ # [\n (?P<base_register>\\w+) # sp\n (\n ,\\s* # , \n [#]? # #\n (?P<offset>\\w+) # 0x8 \n )?\n \\] # ]\n '¶
RE_OFFSET_ADDRESSING_GR_BASE_REGISTER = 'base_register'¶
RE_OFFSET_ADDRESSING_GR_OFFSET = 'offset'¶
RE_REGISTER = '\n \\[? # "[" is optional\n (?P<name>\n (\n [^]] # no ]\n \\S # no whitespace\n )+ # match all but whitespace and ] \n ) \n \\]? # "]" is optional \n '¶
RE_REGISTER_GR_NAME = 'name'¶
RE_STACK_GR_ADDRESS = 'stack_address'¶
RE_STACK_GR_OFFSET = 'stack_offset'¶
RE_STACK_GR_STACK_POINTER = 'stack_pointer'¶
RE_STACK_PUSH_GR_REGISTERS = 'registers'¶
static compiled_re_stack(stack_pointer_name, frame_pointer_name)[source]¶

Return a compiled regular expression that matches e.g. “[sp, #0x8]” or “[sp], #0x4” Use RE_STACK_GR_ADDRESS group key to get the stack address.

Parameters:

stack_pointer_name: string :

the name of stack pointer register (e.g. “sp”)
static compiled_re_stack_push_via_stm(stack_pointer, asmline)[source]¶

Read a stack push via “stm” like e.g. “stm.w sp, {r3, r11}” and return the re match object. Use RE_STACK_PUSH_GR_REGISTERS to get the list<str> of pushed registers

static stack_pointer_sub(stack_pointer_str, asmline)[source]¶

Read a line like e.g. “sub sp, #0x14” and return the value that is being subtracted from the stack pointer as string. None if did not match.

class vizasm.analysis.asm.cpu.arm.Asm_arm.Asm_arm(cpu, parse_util)[source]¶

Bases: vizasm.analysis.asm.cpu.AssignmentMatchingSystem.AssignmentMatchingSystem

The AssignmentMatchingSystem for the arm architecture.

A stack fetch as well as a stack pop set the stack_address. However a fetch from stack will be read and stored in robject.

Parameters:

__stack_push_via_str: bool (default is False) :

indicates if read line is a stack push via “str” (store)

__stack_push_via_stm: bool (default is False) :

indicates if read line is a stack push via “stm” (store multiple)

__stack_fetch_via_prev_sf: bool, (default is True) :

if True, the argument is located on prev_stack_frame rather than on stack

Methods

add_reg_arg_since_last_call(reg, robject) Add a Register to reg_usage_since_last_call if the register is specified as an register holding method arguments.
clear_usage_since_last_call() r0 seems to always keep an argument. Add it to the args if they get cleared
get_c_func_heuristic()
get_cpu()
get_current_stackframe_for_fetch() Depending on stack_fetch_via_prev_sf get the appropriate StackFrame which you can use to get an argument from.
get_is_stack_fetch()
get_is_stack_push()
get_lobject()
get_parse_util()
get_reg_args_since_last_call()
get_robject()
get_stack_address()
get_stack_args_since_last_call()
get_stack_fetch_via_prev_sf()
get_stack_push_objects()
get_stack_push_via_stm()
get_stack_push_via_str()
get_usage_since_last_call() Get the registers and stack usage since the last call.
number_of_arguments_since_last_call() Get the number of arguments that have been seen since the last call.
process_stack_push() Push the objects onto the stack
read_assignment(asmline) Read an assignment and try to split it.
reset() Clear the system.

set_robject(value)
set_stack_address(value) Set the stack address.
set_stack_args_since_last_call(value)
set_stack_fetch_via_prev_sf(value)
set_stack_push_objects(value)
set_stack_push_via_stm(value)
set_stack_push_via_str(value)
clear_usage_since_last_call()[source]¶

r0 seems to always keep an argument. Add it to the args if they get cleared

get_current_stackframe_for_fetch()[source]¶

Depending on stack_fetch_via_prev_sf get the appropriate StackFrame which you can use to get an argument from. Do not use this method to get the StackFrame and read a push

get_is_stack_push()[source]¶
get_stack_fetch_via_prev_sf()[source]¶
get_stack_push_via_stm()[source]¶
get_stack_push_via_str()[source]¶
is_stack_push¶

_is_stack_push: bool (default is False) – indicates if the assignment is a stack push operation. x86_64 example: “mov dword [ss:rsp], 0x7”.

read_assignment(asmline)[source]¶

Read an assignment and try to split it.

Parameters:

asmline : string

line of assembler
reset()[source]¶

Clear the system.

stack_fetch_via_prev_sf¶

__stack_fetch_via_prev_sf(bool, (default is True)) – if True, the argument is located on prev_stack_frame rather than on stack

class vizasm.analysis.asm.cpu.arm.Cpu_arm.Cpu_arm(superclasses_dict=None)[source]¶

Bases: vizasm.analysis.asm.cpu.Cpu.Cpu

Cpu for the arm architecture.

Parameters:

__prev_stack_frame: StackFrame :

Use to read method arguments, cause they are stored in the previous stack frame. See https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/documentation/Xcode/Conceptual/iPhoneOSABIReference/Articles/ARMv6FunctionCallingConventions.html for the stack layout.

Methods

arguments_registers() List of Register which specifies where the arguments are being stored.
arguments_registers_in_sequence() Return True if the destination_register, selector_register, and the selector_arg_registers are specified one behind the other in arguments_registers.
create_and_store_c_func_arguments(method) Create and store the arguments for the function.
destination_register()

next_reg_for_spret(register) If an objc_msgSend_stret is detected, the specified Register for the destination and selector do not match anymore due to the fact that the first argument register is needed for the return address of the structure.
next_regs_for_spret(reg_list) Same as next_reg_for_spret, but do it for the whole list of Register
nslog_arg_registers()

return_reg_is_fst_arg_reg() Check if the return register is also the first argument register
return_register()
selector_arg_registers()
selector_register()

Objective-C runtime for arm arch

store_self_cmd_for_stack_fetching_cpu(...) Store self and _cmd in the appropriate place if the
create_and_store_method_selector_arguments(method_selector)[source]¶

Create the method_selector arguments. The first ones are stored in the registers specified by selector_arg_registers. The remaining ones are pushed onto the stack (beginning at address 0x8)

get_current_selector_check_sel_type(objc_msgSend_stret=False)[source]¶

Overwritten to accept other types as Selector. Currently annotation in Hopper is not so good, leading often to hex values etc. in the selector_register.

msg_send_from_destination(destination, selector)[source]¶

Overwritten to accept other ints as destination. Currently annotation in Hopper is not so good, leading often to hex values (parsed to int) in the destination_register.

static parse_add(asmline)[source]¶

Parse an add statement like e.g. “add r7, sp, #0xc” and return tuple(destination, operand1, operand2). Operand2 can be empty (None).

static parse_assignment_split(asmline)[source]¶

Parse an assignment and split to operation, value before and after comma See RE_ASSINGMENT_SPLIT for details.

Returns:

tuple<string, string, string> :

tuple containing operation, value1, value2
parse_call_instruction(asmline)[source]¶

Read a call instruction like e.g. “blx imp___symbolstub1__objc_msgSend”

parse_imp_got(asmline)[source]¶
parse_imp_stub(asmline)[source]¶

Parse an imp stub like e.g. “imp___symbolstub1__objc_msgSend”

parse_ivar(asmline)[source]¶

Create a ObjcClass from e.g. “IVAR_0x291c”

parse_objc_class_from_classref(asmline)[source]¶
parse_objc_class_from_framework_class(asmline)[source]¶
static parse_offset_addressing(asmline)[source]¶

Parse arm offset addressing like e.g. “[sp, #0x8]” and return the values as a tuple<string> If no offset given, assume 0x0 is offset (e.g. “[sp, #0x8]”)

static parse_offset_addring_offset_needed(asmline)[source]¶

Parse arm offset addressing like e.g. “[sp, #0x8]” and return the values as a tuple<string> Without an offset (meaning a second value seperated by ”,”) this will not match! -> “[r5] does not match!

parse_register(register)[source]¶

Parse a register and wrap it into the Register class. Use this to match as last, cause it will match nearly everything!

parse_stack_access(asmline)[source]¶

Parse a stack access like e.g. “[sp, #0x8]” or “[r7, #0x8]” or “[sp] or “[sp], #0x4”. The latter leads to an address of 0x0.

Returns:

tuple<string, string> :

Return the stack pointer name as well as the stack address as hex string.
parse_stack_pointer_sub(asmline)[source]¶

Read a line like e.g. “sub sp, #0x14” and return the value that is being subtracted from the stack pointer as int. None if did not match.

parse_stack_push_via_stm(asmline, stack_pointer_name)[source]¶

Parse a stack push via “stm” command like e.g. “”stm.w sp, {r3, r11}”.

Parameters:

stack_pointer_name: string :

name of the stack pointer register
Returns:

list<Register> :

list of pushed registers.
parse_var_assignment_with_ivar_ref_from_asmline(asmline)[source]¶

Create a VarAssignment from asmline like e.g. “r0, [r4, r5]”. Try to resolve the ivar_ref of the IVar from the register of the left side of the assignment.

Parameters:

asmline: String :

the asmline should have the form of “r0, [r4, r5]” where the part before the comma is optional. If left out, the ivar_ref cannot be resolved.

cpu: Cpu :

the cpu which is needed for resolving the values of the registers

register_class: class :

the class of the register to create. If non given, a string is used for the register representation.
Returns:

VarAssignment :

the VarAssignment with ivar_ref set (None if no VarAssignment)
Raises:

VarAssignmentResolveSelfrefRegisterException :

if the value cannot be resolved

VarAssignmentResolveIvarRegisterException :

if the value cannot be resolved and resolve_ivar_value is true

VarAssignmentIvarRegisterWrongTypeException :

if the type of the ivar_reg is not IVar and `resolve_ivar_value is true
parse_var_assignment_without_ivar_ref_from_asmline(asmline)[source]¶

Create a VarAssignment from asmline like e.g. “[r4, r5]”

Parameters:

asmline: String :
Returns:

VarAssignment :

the VarAssignment without ivar_ref set (None if no VarAssignment)
Raises:

VarAssignmentResolveSelfrefRegisterException :

if the value cannot be resolved

VarAssignmentResolveIvarRegisterException :

if the value cannot be resolved and resolve_ivar_value is true

VarAssignmentIvarRegisterWrongTypeException :

if the type of the ivar_reg is not IVar and `resolve_ivar_value is true

class vizasm.analysis.asm.cpu.arm.Register_Arm.Register_arm(register)[source]¶

Bases: vizasm.model.asm.Register.Register

Implements an register for the x86_64 architecture

Notes

Register list taken from: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms253983(v=vs.80).aspx and http://www.raywenderlich.com/37181/ios-assembly-tutorial.

Methods

fallback_support(register, register_dict) Returns a list of registers which are equal in the manner that one registers uses the memory space of the other.
